newsitem.title: CANADA: Canadian bonds open weaker, hurt by U.S. losses.
newsitem.headline: Canadian bonds open weaker, hurt by U.S. losses.

text.p: Canadian bonds opened softer in light trading on Friday, amid early weakness in U.S. fixed-income markets and further profit-taking after strong gains recorded this week, analysts said.

"I think people are looking an excuse to sell and they got one in the States. We're just going down with them pretty well lockstep," said Hank Cunningham, director of fixed income with First Marathon Securities Ltd.
Canada's 30-year benchmark bond fell C$0.50 to C$119.25 to yield 6.526 percent.
The U.S. 30-year bond fell 9/32 to yield 6.51 percent. The yields on the bonds moved from trading at par to a positive spread of two basis points.

Both Canadian and U.S. bonds opened the session weaker, with profit-taking hurting prices in both countries. A wider-than-expected U.S. trade deficit also hurt prices in that country, Cunningham said.

The profit-taking follows a session in which the yield on the Canadian 30-year benchmark bond reached record-low yield of 6.472 percent. Analysts said the pullback in bond prices comes as little surpise.

"It all smells of a market top to me, near term anyway. I don't think anybody is abandoning their long-term bull story, but I think it's vulnerable to a little bit of a pullback here," said Cunningham.

The short end of the Canadian yield curve continued to get hit by speculation of a near-term Bank of Canada rate hike. While some money market traders said a weak dollar and signs of an accelerating economy pointed to the need for a rate hike, others said there was little impetus for the central bank to tighten.

In other prices, Canada's 10-year benchmark bond fell C$0.33 to C$109.32 to yield 5.971 percent. The U.S. 10-year bond fell 9/32 to yield 6.23 percent. The negative spread moved to 26 basis points from 24 basis points at Thursday's close.
